Award.AwardTitle: Regression Analysis of Networked Data: Estimating Function Theory and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Network data are pervasive in practice such as genetic network data and social network data. Regression analysis of network data is needed to understand the relationship between a set of network-correlated outcomes and another set of covariates. Accomplishing this task requires fast and efficient estimation and inference methods for the model parameters. This motivates researchers to develop a new regression modeling framework for data arising from either networks with undirected edges or networks with directed edges. Through PI's long-term collaborations in Epidemiology, Environmental Health Sciences, and Nephrology, the studied methods can be used by local scientists who will provide valuable feedback. This new research project can also lead to substantial educational initiatives that will involve undergraduate and graduate students and expose them to the state-of-the-art research in various interdisciplinary topics related to the corresponding research. These include new courses, short courses at major conferences, summer workshops, mentoring, and software development. These and other dissemination activities will increase awareness of modern powerful methods for data analysis among scientists from other fields.

Although the network analysis has been extensively studied in the literature for dependent structures, little has been studied yet in the regression analysis of response-covariate relationships. This project attempts to fill in such a gap through a few steps. Specifically, the PI proposes to study three different but related problems, including network dependence models, estimating functions methodology via the generalized method of moments, and large-sample theory. This research project includes several innovative and efficient statistical procedures based on estimating functions for estimation and inference. It is anticipated that the studied framework will allow researchers to handle a large variety of network-correlated discrete and continuous data.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central task of this project is to understand the relationship between a set of network-correlated outcomes and another set of covariates. Such data arise from many applied fields such as social networks, genetic networks, neurosciences, and spatial networks (e.g. network of air pollution monitors).

Intellectual Merit

To accomplish the proposed task we developed fast and efficient estimation and inference methods for the model parameters. The focus of this proposal has been on the regression analysis of response-covariate relationships with data arising from dependent networks. Specifically, we have made the following new contributions. (i) We developed a new graphic model to estimate network topology using both undirected graphical model and directed acyclic graphical model, where we combined certain prior knowledge-based network structure with a fully data-driven dependence structure by the means of shrinkage estimation. (ii) We developed a novel approach to incorporating knowledge-based prior network topology into estimation and inference, as well as fast computational algorithms in the proposed models. (iii) We established related key large-sample theory for the hybrid quadratic inference function (HQIF) estimator for networks with undirected edges, including estimation consistency and asymptotic normality as well the shrinkage coefficient selection consistency in the network dependence estimation. (iv)We studied the implementation of the proposed models and algorithms in the framework of modern computing frameworks, such as Spark Lambda Architecture and Hadoop, where we specifically developed new theory and methods for both incremental inference in Spark and distributed inference in Hadoop.

Broader Impact.

The research and educational programs made significant contributions in several areas. The major contribution has concerned the development of a new class of multivariate regression models for multilevel networked data. Such data are pervasive in various fields. The PI has close connections with researchers in other fields such as Epidemiology, Environmental Health Sciences, and Nephrology. He has been working closely with these subject-matter scientists who were potential users of the methodologies and provided valuable feedback. For example, the motivating EEG data from the study on adverse effect of iron deficiency on infant recognition memory was PI’s collaborative work with scientists from the UM Center of Human Growth and Development. The PI has tried to disseminate the research results to these and other researchers in application areas. The proposal also included substantial educational initiatives that has involved several graduate students and exposed them to state-of-the-art research in the topics related to the proposal. The PI has given lectures in summer workshops, mentoring, and software development. These and other dissemination activities have increased awareness of modern powerful methods for data analysis among scientists from other fields.


Last Modified: 09/08/2018
Modified by: Peter Song
